subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: brief survey of reading research
msgSnippet: Interesting question, Jeff. I really doubt the importance of phonetic orthography in reading speed, at least with mature, avid readers who are well past the
messageBody:
Interesting question, Jeff.


I really doubt the importance of phonetic orthography in reading speed, at least with mature, avid readers who are well past the sounding-it-out stage. And I imagine the length of some words in German might slow things down a bit--it's better to have Fahrvergnügen than Hoffnunglosigkeit in your Götterdämmerung!

I had a Russian professor tell me that because Russian letters have very few descenders and ascenders, it makes it harder to read than English.  If I recall, one of the reasons Read designed the tall and deep letters the way he did was to increase the number of descenders/ ascenders for easier reading. (But dyslexics got the shaft!)

Another thing that might be interesting to consider would be grammatical redundancy, do inflected languages, where the gender, number and case of nouns and adjectives have to match read faster than those like English with few grammatical endings, or does the redundacy get in the way?

I have a suspicion that the alphabetic languages which might be most difficult would be Hebrew and Arabic, since in ordinary printed material, vowels are not indicated. A lot more has to be inferred by context than in European languages. Anyone know of any studies yea or nay?

Regarding the misspelling in the Lord's Prayer. . . my bad. (forgive me my trespasses!) :-[

Jon



jeff_smith_8992 wrote:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "ouphrontis" <allen_rouse@y...>
wrote:
  
this may be of some interest to the group.

via slashdot

http://www.microsoft.com/typography/ctfonts/WordRecognition.aspx
    

I just finished reading the article "The Science of Word Recognition "
(by Kevin Larson) ... thanks for posting the link to the web site.

With regard to the Read alphabet, I found this statement very interesting:

	"It is well known that words that have a consistent spelling to sound
correspondence such as mint, tint, and hint are recognized faster than
words that have an inconsistent spelling to sound correspondence such
as pint."

If this is true, given enough practice, we should be able to read text
written in QuikScript more rapidly than text written in the normal,
orthodox alphabet. Has anyone become proficient enough in reading
QuikScript text that they would say they can read it faster than they
can read regular text?  Any estimates of how much time and practice it
might take reach this level?

Also, in some languages, words are spelled much more phonetically than
is English (a quick search on the internet says German and Japanese
are two such languages). Does anyone know whether or not people that
use these languages can actually read at faster rates?  Could the
average German read a Harry Potter novel in less time than an average
American?

Jeff
